text: (lively music)
- Hi, my name's Phil Le-Brun.

I'm an Enterprise Strategist
with Amazon Web Services.

Today we're gonna talk
about stakeholder alignment
in the context of digital transformations.
We know that many digital transformations
don't see the full return expected
because of a lack of common understanding

of what digital actually
means in an organization.

Today, we want to
examine the critical role

stakeholder alignment plays
in such transformations

and how you drive that
through a combination
of increasing digital literacy
and breaking down silos to generate

cross-functional initiatives
in an organization.

I'm delighted to have
Gavin Munroe join me today.
Gavin is the Global CIO
for Wealth and Personal Banking at HSBC.
Gavin, thank you for joining me.
Gavin, could you introduce yourself,

your role at HSBC and a
little bit about HSBC itself?

- Thanks for Phil, and
thanks for having me.
So, as you said, my name is Gavin Munroe

and I'm the Global CIO for
Wealth and Personal Banking, WPB.
I lead a team of 18,000 people
across 46 different countries
supporting 36 million customers,
supporting our retail, private banking,
wealth and insurance businesses.

I've been in the technology
space for 25 years

from retail, telecom, all
the way up to now in finance.
And I've always found it fascinating
how technology can influence our lives
and the opportunity technology brings.
I don't think there's a more exciting time

than what we are in now
with what technology can do.
You think about the transformation

that the financial
industry is going through,
it is led by technology.
If you think about where multiple
of these industries are going,
be it the EV, electric vehicle,
be it even global warming,

technology is what's gonna
help us get through this.
So being a part of that
and being part of the technology industry,
helping drive that business strategy
is a privilege and an honor.

- And digital transformation
in an organization like HSBC,
a mammoth organization,
must be a pretty complex undertaking.

What does it mean in the
context of your business?
- Yes, that's a great question, Phil.
Digital transformation means many things

and in a lot of cases,
it's probably overused.
The way we think about is two ways.

Firstly, we want to accelerate
what we're doing in the bank.

We want to move away from your
traditional digital channels
to actually being a digital bank
and offering digital products.
And then secondly,

we need to basically innovate
at scale and velocity.

And coming out of the
digital transformation,

we need to be able to do
that, to remain relevant.

What we are offering as
a bank needs to evolve,

and to do that, we have to
get that to the market quicker
and we have to innovate at scale.
We look at scale as our advantage today
or, not as our advantage today,
we want to make it our advantage.

But in most cases, scale
can be a disadvantage.
So unless we can transform,
unless we can digitize the bank,
we can't leverage that scale.

If we look at what COVID has
done over the last 12 months,
it's just accelerated that digital demand
and that digital transformation.

So we want to leverage that
momentum and move forward.
If you look HSBC as an example, Phil,
we have one in two customer interactions
or transactions is digital,
the fastest growing platform.
So we want to continue to leverage that
and then digitize it at the bank's core.

The other part that is
part of our transformation
is the data side.
With digitizing our products,
with digitizing the core bank,
we are actually have access to more data.

And the opportunity for us
is to how to leverage that,
to service our customers better.

So hyper-personalization
is a word used a lot,
but we really do believe in it.

So how can we bring
real time decisionings?

And this is not the
decisionings that we used to do
when we talk about data,
it's not fraud and cyber,

but how do we benefit
the customer interaction?
How can we give you balanced forecasting?

How can we give you next
projected investment options
all real time?

To do that, we have to leverage
that data that we've got,

we have to leverage the
power of cloud as an example,

and drive that capability
into the customer's hand
so they can see it real time.
As an example, the last 12 months,

we've basically doubled
our cloud hosted services.
And why have we done that?

Partly because we want
the containerization,
partly because we want the pipelines,
automation, CI/CD DevOps,
but the other thing is to leverage
the compute power of the cloud

to be able to do that
real time decisioning.

So we've got to move more
stuff onto the cloud,

we've got to be ready for
that on-demand scalability,

and that innovation, the ability
to stand up environments,
the ability to react quickly.
That's what the cloud brings to us.

And that's what we want
to bring to our customers.
- It's fantastic hearing the story.
Banking, you wouldn't traditionally hear
some of what you've talked about
with experimentation and personalization.
So, some great insights there.
One of the questions that often comes up
when we're talking to customers is,
what does digital transformation mean?
What is digital to an organization?
How did you get clarity within HSBC
about what it meant to your business?
- I think it's a question that
every company has to answer themselves.
I don't think there's one size fits all.
And we looked at what our customers want
and what they're expecting from us.
And we know that they are evolving.

We have to evolve as a
company to service that.

I think if you look at
your traditional banks,
you have a bunch of products,
mortgage, credit card,
and you have a bunch of channels.

That's not how the
customers see us anymore.
So we had to evolve and look at,
we have to transform the company

to be customer-focused
and value proposition-led.

And we have to change the
core of the actual bank
and move away from legacy thinking.
When we think about the old world
where you walk into a bank,
we control that environment.
We know when you're in our facility,
we know when you walk up to the ATM,
and it's a controlled, secure environment.
In the modern world,
the political boundaries don't count,
country boundaries don't count.
The actual perimeter that we engaging
the customer has moved.

It's either moved online,
it's either moved B2B.
When you make a purchase on Amazon,
there's an FX trade behind that.
All those different engagement points
are out of our control.
So we have to be able to provide
a service to those customers
in whatever form or fashion they want.

That's the objective of
our digital transformation,

to be able to facilitate
those transactions

or engage with those
customers at their time, 24/7,
and where they operate and what they want.

That's how we define our
digital transformation.

- We hear a lot of these buzz
words in industries today.
We've talked about digital transformation
and what it means to HSBC.
Another word that's often used is agile.
What does that mean in your organization?
- Hm, it's a great question.

So I wouldn't say we
are a mature agile shop.
We are on the journey to be an agile shop.

And we probably say we do a
lot of small a, but not big A.

But we are striving to
be a mature agile shop.

And the reason why that's
important for us is,
it's tied to this digital transformation.

As I mentioned, innovate
at scale, and at velocity.
You can't get that velocity
unless you have a mature agile shop.
So we going through this transformation.
We have aligned our organization around
customer outcome, customer proposition.

So we moved away from
product silos or P&L silos,

and we're pivoting towards
delivery and delivery at pace.

So we've gone through
the low hanging fruit,
which is the tools, JIRA, Confluence,
we've aligned all those,
but honestly, that's the easy part.
It's the cultural transformation,

it's the organizational
alignment that has to do this.
We do tie agile transformation
to our digital transformation.

'Cause as I mentioned, the
velocity is what's key for us.
So we are on the early stages of that
and we're going through this journey.
But we're trying to get at its core.

We're trying to get
autonomous bodies of teams

or groups of teams that are
able to run self-contained
within their own construct,

within their own
organizational constructs.

And then we empower them
to deliver on value outcome
and customer-led metrics.
So we tie back in the customer-led metrics
like NPS scores and stuff like that

into how we measure success
in our agile transformation.

- It's a very different way
of running an organization.
You're pushing a lot more decisions
down to these autonomous teams.
How have they received that change?
- So I think it's a journey.
I think some of them have gravitated to it

and picked it up like a duck
in water and gone with it,
and others haven't.
I mean like any transformation,
I think the big problem with,
well, not the big problem but,

the big opportunity for
agile as well as digital,
it's easy on paper.
When you put agile or digital on a paper,

it's like, well, why
wouldn't anybody do this?
But it's the size of the organization
that makes it difficult.
It's the culture of the organization
that makes it difficult.

So when I say we're on a
journey, we've laid it out.
But I think we've got to land

and then we've got to
repeat, repeat, repeat
to make sure it sticks.
And I think that's the process we're in.
We know what we're trying to do.

We have mapped it out with
data, we know how to measure it,

but we've got to repeat
and we've got to repeat
and we've got to mature.

There isn't an on/off or
there isn't a right/wrong.
There's a level of maturity

that we are going down
the journey to adopt it.
And that's where we are.

- I'd love to hear that
'cause you are dealing
with a complex organization
with people and lots of moving parts

and that idea that you're
going to make changes,
sense and respond,

is just seemingly an
eminently practical way

of driving such a large
scale transformation.
- Definitely.
I think about the digital transformation

as well as the agile
transformation as steps.

And if you're trying to
define the end state upfront

before you get going, you're
probably never gonna get going.
I mean for us, we've really defined,
what is the next step?

What is the actions we have
to take to get to that step?
And how are we gonna measure that step?

So long as you have data to
measure what success looks like,

and then you can reflect
on it and go forward.
I think the biggest part of that

is really being able to
adjust the journey as you go.
And take the metrics you've got,
take the data you've got,
but continue to evolve.
Like I said in my initial intro,

the financial industry is
going through a transformation.

No one can sit here and say
they know what it looks like.
So the person that tells you,

"We know what it's gonna
look like in 10 years,"
probably not really realistic.

So the only thing we can
do is start the journey,
and course-correct as we go.
That's where you need data,
that's where you need custom engagement,

that's where you need a 360
loop to be able to reflect that
and then adjust as you go.
And take it step-by-step.

- You are at the start of
your journey around agile.
And you've talked about innovation
being so core to HSBC's future.

What have you seen in
terms of early results
from your agile transformation,
and what could be possible
with the ability to innovate in the bank?
- So let's be clear.
At HSBC, our opportunity is scale,
but it's also our weak point.

And when we think about the
countries we operate in,
we operate in 46 different countries,
we want to get our mobile app

in the hands of those
customers as quick as possible.
So that's where cloud comes in,
the ability to deploy in country
where we don't even have a footprint,
as an example, is imperative for us.
And the ability to do that
at a low cost point to us is critical.
So we have a good example.
Something like, we call it Global Money.

So Global Money is our
mobile multicurrency app

that doesn't behave like
a normal multicurrency app

in that it runs on the local
payment rails in the country.
We launched it in the US this year

and we want to roll it
out to approximately
10 other countries in the next 12 months.
So to do that, we need a standard pattern,

we need a standard pipeline
to build it and to deploy it.
And then we need to be able to maintain it
in country at a low cost footprint.

So we're leveraging the cloud
environment to innovate,

we're leveraging the cloud
environment to deploy at scale,
but then we also have a single code base

servicing over 10 million
customers in these 10 countries.
So it's imperatively combining
the innovation with the scale

to basically be our
advantage, not a disadvantage.
- I love the way you framed that
because often we talk about innovation
as being the thing you've just built,

but instead thinking
about how do you innovate
around getting that thing into the hands
of millions of your customers quickly
is a really interesting way

I'm sure many people
will be really interested
in learning more about that.
- Yeah, I think it's a great point.

I think we think about velocity
as part of our innovation,
if we can innovate around velocity,
'cause that's the competitive advantage.

Big organizations don't
have that velocity.
Fintechs do, tech companies do.

So we've got to figure
out how to bring velocity

to our organization, to
our business partners.
And that's why I look at our tech
as a strategic lever to deliver on that.

- So one of the challenges
we often see in organizations

is digital transformations
need to start at the top.
This is more than just technology clearly.

How did you drive that alignment
with your peers in HSBC
to make sure that there was clarity
about what this journey looked like?
- We actually are very fortunate in WPB.
One of our core strategies or enablers
is digital enablement.
Sorry, one of our core objectives
is digital enablement in HSBC.

So we started where probably
most companies started.
We stood up a digital division

and we gave them the
remit of being digital.
And they did what they did.
They created a mobile app,
they created a browser.
And it actually worked.
And it was fit for purpose
and it got us past hurdle number one.
But we soon realized that
that's not going to create a digital bank,
it's not gonna create digital products.
It was basically just a channel.

And it was good, it worked
for what it worked for.
But since then, we've actually said,

"Okay, well, we need to
make the bank digital
and we need to embed digital thinking
in the rest of the organization."

So we've taken that entity,
that digital division,

and we've actually pushed
it into the organization.

So for a period, we had
a digital product owner
and a product owner.

And over time, we ended up
with one digital product owner.

Sometimes it was a digital
person that took the role
and sometimes it was the product owner,
traditional product owner,
who learned the digital skillsets.

But over time, we've ended
up with one organization,
one leadership structure around digital.

It's everybody's
responsibility to be digital.
And as I mentioned previously,

we started to think about
our customer differently.

So we started to orientate
the organization differently.
Instead of your traditional P&L,
which associated a customer like yourself
with a branch down the street,
and that's where the profit landed

and that's where the
accountability landed,
we've broken those silos away

from traditional P&Ls and
traditional boundaries,

and we've looked at our
customer differently.
Our customer's global,

our customer doesn't exist
through a single site.

And we've also looked
at our value proposition
as not only product but services.
So it's customer-orientated thinking,
it's value proposition,

and that's how we've organized
the digital inside the bank.
That's allowed us to basically pivot
from the way we do agile,
to the way we measure customer success,

to the way we actually
deliver for our customer.

- So it sounds like while you
started with an organization

that was building digital
things like your mobile app,
it's really become more of a,

how do you use that team
to drive a cultural change
and embedding a different way of thinking
throughout your organization?

- Exactly, it's all of our
responsibility to be digital.
If we really gonna pivot the organization

from traditional bank to
a digital organization,
it's critical for all of us to do it.
I give you a great example.
I mean, as I said, scale is our problem,
but once we figure out how to automate it,
once we figure out how to digitize it,
we can achieve some great objectives.

A good example is, we have
moved over the last 12 months.

We've probably doubled
our cloud hosted services,
like I mentioned.

But that has enabled us
to move 96% of our payment

goes through end-to-end
without being touched.
And you say, "Well, 96%, that's great.
Why is it not 99%?"
That is our objective.
But it's 96% of $560 trillion a year

goes through HSBC
payment rails, untouched.

So that scale, once we can
figure out how to automate it,

once we can figure out to
innovate it, is our advantage.
- They're incredible numbers.
You must wake up at night thinking,

wow, that's quite a
responsibility you have globally.

So we've talked about
culture around digital,
digital products.
What about digital literacy?

How did you ensure that
everyone in the organization

understood what digital
was and felt comfortable
that they had the right knowledge

to have that digital
mindset you described?
- Yeah it's a journey we're on, still.
I think we are maturing it.
But the way we thought about it was,
you know, we've moved away from some
of the traditional project thinking.

So you measure your project
by yellow, red, green;
you have a project budget;
and you have a specific business case
which is measured in dollars.
We flipped it over and we said,
"Okay, as we're go into agile,
we're gonna start doing capacity,
we're gonna start doing value proposition.

And then we're using different
metrics to measure that."
So it's release frequency,

it is time to production
and stuff like that.

And then when we lay over
the digital transformation,
we've brought in the customer metrics.
So NPS scores, custom engagement scores,
the scores I mentioned to you about,
you know, straight through processing,

the metric I mentioned about
digital active customers.
We're bringing that all into the process.
So part of being a digital organization,
you have a lot more data.

The opportunities, how do
you create a feedback loop
in your transformation
so that you can make the right decisions
based on things like customer metrics,
customer feedback, NPS,

as well as adoption metrics
and things like that,
tied to the digital frequency,
sorry, tied to the agile velocity,
you'd be able to course-correct
and continue to evolve your offerings,

bringing that into your
decision-making process.

- Have you had to put in
training programs, for example,

to help people get into
that mindset you described?

- Definitely. I think it's
a different cultural set.
And it starts at the top.

I mean, we started with
coaches at the executives.

we all know anybody that's gone through
an agile transformation,
you have a team that's trying to do agile,

and, you know, executives
are asking for waterfall.
Likewise, it applies to digital as well.
You know, if you're still gonna measure
your outcome by a business case of dollars

and I'm not saying dollars
is not important, it is,
but you need to bring that customer lens,
you need to become customer-obsessed

and that feedback loop
need to be in there.
So, yes, we needed to apply training.
We continued to have scorecards.

And we've rolled these
scorecards out globally.
So we are measuring this global adoption

of the digital transformation
using scorecard.
You need make it data-driven.
You need to base it fact-driven.
So you do need scorecards.

And everybody say, "Well,

able to measure your progress

and otherwise you won't
be able to set objectives

on each step, like I
mentioned in the beginning.
You need to find those steps.
So you do need the data-driven approach
to be able to navigate the journey.
- It's really interesting.
You talk about bringing in agile coaches,

even at the senior levels
of your organization.

in organizations, we have this tendency

to start projects almost

How did you make sure that
at the executive level,

people stayed engaged with
this transformation throughout

- It's a little bit about the
connecting it to the customer.

So when we all speak in
the customer language

and we all bring that customer
metric to our objectives,
we all have shared objectives.

It's not a technology

When we combined those and

- That's great to hear.

I don't know about you, but
this business and IT thing,
it sounds like you've got over that

let's talk about the customer instead.
- Exactly, I mean like I said previously,
it's a maturity scale.
So in some regions, we are there,
some regions we are not.
But we know how to measure it.
So we are on that journey.

- I imagine people watching
this, top of their mind is,

if they're starting their
transformation journey,

what's two or three pieces
of advice you'd give them

as they start to think
about how to get going?
- So if I reflect on our journey,
I probably would summarize it this way.

First was, we transformed
the entire organization.

It's not about just
delivering a digital product.

It's actually about
transforming the organization
and change in the organization.

And for us, we realized,
innovation at scale
and delivery of velocity is key to us.
So we pivot around that primary purpose.
We needed to do that on the cloud

because I don't think we
could have achieved it.

I mean, nothing's wrong with
the legacy infrastructure,
nothing's wrong with our data centers,
but to innovate at scale and at pace,
we needed a more flexible option.

So that was the first
thing, is think about

how your organization has
to realign to achieve this.

Then the second one is
actually quite simple.
It is, define your first step to take,

figure out the data you
need to measure that,
and take that step.

I think the only advice
I would give somebody is,

there's never a good time to
start a digital transformation,

but there is a wrong
time and that's tomorrow.
'Cause you need to start today.
The curve has already started.

- So it's think big about
what your future aspirations
could be as an organization,

but then don't bog yourself
down trying to over-plan.

Just get started and
course-correct as you go along.

- And course-correct
is the key over there.
I think no one really knows
what this journey's gonna be like.

to the financial service industry.

I mean, look at Amazon when
they first were selling books.

It's completely different.

they never designed the original,

about technology,

I'm passionate of the

those kinds of data points

- What's next for HSBC and what

- So HSBC's at a very exciting time.
As I mentioned previously,

the financial industry is
going through a transformation,
and HSBC is at the crux of that.

There's probably not a
larger financial institution
